moves.1. d4: A brief game that felt more like a blitz game rather than a correspondence game.
moves.2... e6 3. Bg5 Be7 4. Nbd2 d5 5. e3 c5 6: A typical torre position, staid and safe. The best part of the torre is that it can result in some impressive fireworks for the unobservant.
moves.8... c4: My book on the torre discourages the pawn push as it removes the tension and black loses dynamic play.
moves.9. Bc2: White keeps his lsb glaring longingly at h7, the lynchpin that has undone many a careless player.
moves.9... Qb6 10. e4: White concluded that it was better to trade the three pawns for a piece with a strong attack on the black King.
moves.10... Qxb2: So it begins, black neglects development for several pawns in exchange for a knight.
moves.11. e5 Qxc3 12. exf6 Nxf6 13. Re1: Black should move the queen now instead of allowing white the rook lift with tempo.
moves.13... Re8 14. Re3 Qa5 15. Ne5: White is applying more pressure and now has free reign along the third rank with his rook.
moves.15... Nd7: A serious misscalculation that leads to a loss
moves.16. Bxh7+: The lynchpin has now fallen, black's best try is kf8 which only postpones the inevitable. He instead chooses a faster route to enlightenment.
moves.16... Kxh7 17. Qh5+ Kg8: From here Qxf7 and Rh3 are just as effective.
